road a mile
and
be
away
from the danger point.
That I could assure him that in
case of
attack that
at least half of everyneepresent would be killed and maybe
seventy-five percent;
that we would not have an even chance, and under such con-
ditions his baggage
was nothing.
So they came with me.
The other side was a
sight.
Rule one on page one in Military Transport is to keep the roads unblocked
at any cost,
but these
damn fools were parked as tightly as possible all over the
road when they
would have advanced their own cause by lining up properly on one
side of
the road,
and
both ramps to the ferry were full.
Fortunately for us the
first truck in line was a big army truck heavily loaded and guarded by six soldiers.
They had to go
up about a 45 degree incline to get on the ferry and their truck
couldn't make it,
so we helped them push and
got them on.
I had passed around
cigarettes and
they became very friendly and one of the Chinese passengers told
them our trouble.
So they told us to come on and go back with them and they would
get us on the ferry.
said,
We asked them how were we going to get off on this side.
They
"Sit on the ferry until these fellows back up and clear the road.
They can't
get on until you get
off."
That made a hell of a lot of sense. to us and we piled
back on the ferry and
went back over.
They were as good as their word and talked
turkey to the ferry official, moved our car up to the head of the line and put us
on.
Then the ferry
official got
cold feet and demanded that the soldiers go back
over and get us off.
But the soldiers said they couldn't do that as they had to
hurry but
for us to
stay on the ferry until we got off on the other side.
We
promised to do that.
The ferry finally started back with much grumbling from the
ferry
people.
When
we
got over the drivers of the other side raised hell and re-
fused
to move.
We refused to go back and asked them to figure out the answer.
They finally backed up so we could get off and we went on our way rejoicing.
But
I looked
back and all
the trucks had scrambled back to their old positions and the
road
and
ferry
landing
was blocked again.
And I thought to myself "I hope all
you bastards get killed",
the good old A.E.F. wise crack.
We got to Shanghai by
seven-thirty A.M.
The
weather started raining and misting again so those half wits
got away
with it
as there was no flying that day.
The
my
first day was very quiet and still is.
If I could stay in
Shanghai
I would bring you out.
I see the papers talk of a terrific bombardment
but I
don't know.
Last night they shelled Lunghtla from a point about north of our
house and
far away.
You could trace the course of the shells by their sound
passing almost directly over our house.
I couldn't figure it out until I saw this
morning
that Lunghwa had been shelled. I put chairs against the doors of our bed-
room
to
stop
fxox
them from rattling, but I slept o.K.
The Chinese certainly have been putting up a grand fight around here.
More power to them.
Amá»™h
Everything at 279 is perfectly O.K.
Li and the coolie were on the job.
came
around and
gave her two months pay and told her to try to find another
job as I
didn't know when you would be back.
She said she would come back to you
when you
did.
I paid the
house rent for Oct. and Nov.
Bix paid it for Sept.
I
offered the house on a
temporary basis to Karl Hill for $200.00.
That's all he
can pay.
If
comes back and want it he will take it.
They will use their
own silver and linens.
I am going to leave all our flat silver with Max Polin.
That is all I can do now.
I must be back in Nanking Wednesday. Out outlook
(Company) is
tough.
There is a great deal of misunderstanding.
The most important
Chinese
think
ran
out on them.
I have accomplished a little but not much
